channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Savannah Guthrie Addresses Mother’s Abductor: ‘We Are Ready to Talk’
item.description: Ms. Guthrie, the television anchor, and her siblings released a video on Wednesday night asking for proof that their mother, Nancy, is alive.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Reis Thebault

item.title: China’s Xi Presses Trump on Taiwan in Phone Call
item.description: Both leaders gave versions of what they discussed, but the Chinese president’s take made clear the issue of the island was front and center.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China in South Korea in October.

item.title: Man Who Falsely Claimed He Killed Charlie Kirk Is Sentenced to Prison
item.description: The authorities said the man, George Zinn, tried to derail their search for Mr. Kirk’s actual killer. He faces up to 15 years in prison on obstruction of justice and other charges.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man who falsely claimed to have killed the conservative activist Charlie Kirk faces up to 15 years in prison after pleading no contest to a felony charge of obstruction of justice.

item.title: Trump Says His Unpredictable Style Gives Him Leverage. But It Has a Cost.
item.description: A year into President Trump’s second term, his threats, retreats, twists and turns appear to be wearing on allies and adversaries.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Tuesday. White House officials say his negotiating style has yielded results, pointing to new trade deals and peace deals.

item.title: Newsom, Shapiro and Other Democrats Whip Up the 2028 Book Buzz
item.description: A number of potential presidential candidates are releasing memoirs as the shadow primary heats up.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Evan Agostini/Invision, via Associated Press; Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Gov. Gavin Newsom of California are both promoting books.

item.title: University of Southern California Names a Lawyer, Beong-Soo Kim, as Its New President
item.description: The president, Beong-Soo Kim, had served on an interim basis and already faced pressure from the Trump administration to join a higher education compact to follow a set of conservative ideas. He refused.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Juliana Yamada/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Beong-Soo Kim previously served the school as senior vice president and general counsel and was a lecturer at the U.S.C. Gould School of Law.

item.title: In Forcing the Clintons to Testify on Epstein, Comer Sets a New Precedent
item.description: The Republican chairman’s successful targeting of a former president who faces no charge of wrongdoing was the sort of tactic typical in an autocracy where leaders fear being jailed when they are out of power.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative James R. Comer of Kentucky, at the Capitol on Tuesday, had been trying for months to get Bill and Hillary Clinton to testify in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

item.title: Pregnant Women in Minneapolis Hiding From ICE Face Impossible Choice
item.description: Health care providers across Minnesota have reported federal immigration agents present in and around medical centers. As arrests continue across the state, expecting mothers are afraid to go to their appointments — and reconsidering their birth plans.
item.dc:creator: Bethlehem Feleke, Ben Garvin and Ben Laffin
item.media:credit: Ben Garvin for The New York Times

item.title: Bessent Says Fed Lacks Accountability and Has Lost Public Trust
item.description: In a House committee hearing, the Treasury secretary declined to say if the president has the power to fire a member of the central bank’s board.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent testified on Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee.

item.title: San Francisco Bay Area Is Skeptical ICE Won’t Target the Super Bowl
item.description: Federal officials said ICE would not conduct enforcement raids in the region this week. But leaders in the San Francisco Bay Area have passed “anti-ICE” ordinances, and activists have planned rapid response efforts nonetheless.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Minh Connors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters stood outside the San Jose McEnery Convention Center in downtown San Jose, Calif., on Monday to make a statement against ICE enforcement.

item.title: Supreme Court Clears Way for California Voting Map
item.description: The state’s Republican Party had asked the justices to step in and block the new congressional maps, which give an advantage to Democrats, before the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sorting ballots at a processing center in City of Industry, Calif., after the special election in November that asked the state’s voters to approve a new congressional map.

item.title: Educators Sue to Keep Immigration Agents From Schools and Bus Stops
item.description: The lawsuit is challenging a Trump administration policy allowing federal agents near locations such as schools, churches and hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the security team for the school district in Fridley, Minn., monitored neighborhoods near local schools during dismissal last week amid heightened federal immigration enforcement activity.

item.title: In Spending Talks, Senators Clash Over Immigration Crackdown
item.description: Democrats’ push to rein in federal agents, and Republican opposition, reflect opposite views of whether the deportation drive should be bound by standard law enforcement rules.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse and Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The clash reflects a fundamental divide between the two parties over how President Trump’s deportation drive should be carried out.

item.title: Have You Been Impacted by the Affordability Crisis? Tell Us.
item.description: We want to hear about how costs are having an impact on your life.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A child-care center in Brooklyn, N.Y.

item.title: Ryan Routh, Man Convicted of Trying to Assassinate Trump, Gets Life Sentence
item.description: Federal prosecutors told the judge that Ryan Routh had “plotted painstakingly” to ambush Donald J. Trump in 2024 at his golf course near West Palm Beach.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Last month, federal prosecutors recommended a life sentence, saying that Mr. Routh had “plotted painstakingly” to stake out Mr. Trump at the Trump International Golf Club West Palm Beach.

item.title: Prosecutor Fired After Voicing Frustration With Immigration Caseload
item.description: The prosecutor, Julie T. Le, told a judge that she and her colleagues in the U.S. attorney’s office were overwhelmed by the White House’s immigration operation in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Hamed Aleaziz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents arrest an individual in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Epstein Helped Woody Allen’s Daughter Get Into College, Emails Show
item.description: Bard College’s president, Leon Botstein, agreed to help Woody Allen and Soon-Yi Previn’s daughter after Jeffrey Epstein connected them, emails released by the Justice Department show.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel and Marc Tracy
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Woody Allen and Soon-Yi Previn’s daughter attended Bard College, in Annadale-On-Hudson, N.Y.

item.title: Melinda French Gates Addresses New References to Bill Gates in Epstein Files
item.description: Messages in the latest Epstein files suggesting that Bill Gates had engaged in extramarital sex brought up “painful” memories, his former wife said in an interview. Mr. Gates has denied the claims.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Elaine Thompson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates in 2019, before their divorce in 2021.

item.title: Texas A&M Lecturer Who Was Fired Over Gender Lesson Sues University
item.description: In a federal lawsuit, the lecturer, Melissa McCoul, accused the university of violating the First Amendment.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Texas A&M campus in College Station, Texas.

item.title: Trump Says He Ordered Withdrawal of 700 Immigration Agents From Minneapolis
item.description: About 2,000 personnel will be left in Minnesota, where President Trump’s immigration crackdown has generated outrage.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said his administration’s approach would continue to be “tough” and he urged local officials to cooperate with federal immigration officers.

item.title: Lee H. Hamilton, a Foreign Policy Force in Congress, Dies at 94
item.description: A moderate Democrat from Indiana for 34 years, he led the House Foreign Affairs and Intelligence committees and helped investigate the Iran-contra scandal and the Sept. 11 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.category: National Commission on Terrorist Attacks upon the United States
item.media:credit: Stephen Crowley/The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Representative Lee H. Hamilton in 1994. A Democrat, he was re-elected 16 times in a largely Republican district.

item.title: Trump’s Call to ‘Nationalize’ Elections Adds to State Officials’ Alarm
item.description: Some top state election officials, who run voting across the country, worry that the federal government has become hostile to them and their work.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Democratic state election officials, including Shenna Bellows, secretary of state in Maine, have spoken out about President Trump’s efforts to involve the administration in election and voting matters.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie’s Missing Mother Has Nation Fixated on an Arizona Subdivision
item.description: The disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, mother of the news anchor Savannah Guthrie, has reporters, neighbors and drones flooding streets and foothills in Tucson, Ariz.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault
item.media:credit: Jan Sonnenmair/Getty Images
item.media:description: Nancy Guthrie’s home became a focus for the fascination of neighbors and the nation alike.

item.title: Fulton County in Georgia Challenges the F.B.I.’s Seizure of 2020 Ballots
item.description: The county filed a motion demanding the return of ballots and other election materials that were seized by the F.B.I. in a highly unusual move by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: F.B.I. agents searched an election center in Fulton County, Ga., last week and seized ballots and other election materials.

item.title: Search for Nancy Guthrie, Savannah Guthrie’s Mother, Grows More Urgent
item.description: The authorities made urgent pleas for help from the public as they tried to locate the “Today” anchor’s 84-year-old mother, who was reported missing in Arizona on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Don Arnold/WireImage, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Savannah Guthrie with her mother, Nancy Guthrie, in Sydney, Australia, in 2015.

item.title: Ex-Capitol Police Officer Harry Dunn Seeks Maryland House Seat
item.description: Mr. Dunn, who rose to prominence for defending the Capitol during the Jan. 6 riot, will run for a hotly contested Southern Maryland seat.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Harry Dunn came in second out of 22 candidates in the Democratic primary for a different Maryland district two years ago.

item.title: What the Crackdown Has Done to Minneapolis Children
item.description: “It’s like living in fear all the time,” a teenager said about the federal raids that have shattered families.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xochitl Soberanes, 16, right, helped care for her younger siblings while her father was detained by immigration officials.

item.title: Republicans Try to Save John Cornyn From Ken Paxton’s Challenge in Texas Senate Race
item.description: Senator John Cornyn, once seen as a potential Republican leader in his chamber, is now depending on wealthy party donors to survive a right-wing challenge.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Allies of Senator John Cornyn of Texas have spent about $50 million on advertising on his behalf since last July as he faces a tough Republican primary challenge next month.

item.title: Minneapolis Police Chief Fears Long-Term Damage From Immigration Crackdown
item.description: Brian O’Hara, who took over a troubled police force and has spent years rebuilding community trust, fears the long-term damage wrought by federal agents.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: “There’s been a real change in this police department,” Chief Brian O’Hara said. “It’s totally different than it was five years ago, 10 years ago. It is very, very fragile, though.”

item.title: How Universities and States Are Increasing Surveillance of Professors
item.description: Scrutiny of university classrooms is being formalized, with new laws requiring professors to post syllabuses and tip lines for students to complain.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Texas and elsewhere, professors must share their syllabuses online. Some faculty members worry about censorship.
